evidence.detectionMethod: Genotyping by Affymetrix Genome-Wide Human SNP Array 6.0 refining the region of homozygosity to a 10.6 Mb region between RS2628473 and RS1901284 (Table S5) containing 71 genes. The authors focused on sequencing 11 candidate genes within the locus based on phenotypic correlation with Jalili syndrome.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The combination of recessively inherited cone-rod dystrophy (CRD) and amelogenesis imperfecta (AI) was first reported by Jalili and Smith in 1988 in a family subsequently linked to a locus on chromosome 2q11, and it has since been reported in a second small family. We have identified five further ethnically diverse families cosegregating CRD and AI. Phenotypic characterization of teeth and visual function in the published and new families reveals a consistent syndrome in all seven families, and all link or are consistent with linkage to 2q11, confirming the existence of a genetically homogenous condition that we now propose to call Jalili syndrome. Using a positional-candidate approach, we have identified mutations in the CNNM4 gene, encoding a putative metal transporter, accounting for the condition in all seven families. Nine mutations are described in all, three missense, three terminations, two large deletions, and a single base insertion. We confirmed expression of Cnnm4 in the neural retina and in ameloblasts in the developing tooth, suggesting a hitherto unknown connection between tooth biomineralization and retinal function. The identification of CNNM4 as the causative gene for Jalili syndrome, characterized by syndromic CRD with AI, has the potential to provide new insights into the roles of metal transport in visual function and biomineralization.
dc:source.dc:creator: Parry DA
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in CNNM4 cause Jalili syndrome, consisting of autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy and amelogenesis imperfecta.

evidence.rdfs:label: Scotland_III:1

evidence.detectionMethod: Genotyping by Affymetrix Genome-Wide Human SNP Array 6.0 refining the region of homozygosity to a 10.6 Mb region between RS2628473 and RS1901284 (Table S5) containing 71 genes.  The authors focused on sequencing 11 candidate genes within the locus based on phenotypic correlation with Jalili syndrome.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: linkage analysis using microsatellites identified region of homozygosity in achromtopsia locus 2p11. Candidate gene CNGA3 was sequenced at the 5' UTR and exons using Sanger, however no causal mutations were found
evidence.rdfs:label: Gaza A_VIII:10

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole-genome linkage analysis was performed on Family A which had similar phenotypes with the same diagnosis of Jalili syndrome.  Therefor Sanger sequencing of the exons in candidate genes within the region of homozygosity on chromosome 2 which includes rs2970925- rs953320region identified in family A was performed.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cone-rod dystrophies are inherited dystrophies of the retina characterized by the accumulation of deposits mainly localized to the cone-rich macular region of the eye. Dystrophy can be limited to the retina or be part of a syndrome. Unlike nonsyndromic cone-rod dystrophies, syndromic cone-rod dystrophies are genetically heterogeneous with mutations in genes encoding structural, cell-adhesion, and transporter proteins. Using a genome-wide single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) haplotype analysis to fine map the locus and a gene-candidate approach, we identified homozygous mutations in the ancient conserved domain protein 4 gene (CNNM4) that either generate a truncated protein or occur in highly conserved regions of the protein. Given that CNNM4 is implicated in metal ion transport, cone-rod dystrophy and amelogenesis imperfecta may originate from abnormal ion homeostasis.
dc:source.dc:creator: Polok B
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in CNNM4 cause recessive cone-rod dystrophy with amelogenesis imperfecta.

evidence.previousTestingDescription: Previous testing was carried out in PMID 15173235.  Genotyping was carried out using microsatellite marker DS2187 that had been previously shown to be linked to Jalili syndrome.  Mutation screening of coding regions of CNGA3 via Sanger sequencing was also performed.  The marker D2S2187 was determined to segregate with CRD/AI in the family however no causal mutations were found in CNGA3.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kosovo_II:1

evidence.dc:description: Downgrading the score because the individuals is homozygous, per discussion with the Experts in the Retina GCEP.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole-genome linkage analysis was performed with the Affymetrix human mapping 50K XbaI array. A 5.4Mb region of homozygosity on chromosome 2 was identified that includes rs2970925- rs953320 which have been linked to this disease.  Sanger sequencing of candidate genes within the region was performed.
evidence.rdfs:label: II:1

evidence.dc:description: Downgrading the score because the individuals is homozygous, per discussion with the Experts in the Retina GCEP.

evidence.detectionMethod: Affymetrix Genome-Wide Human SNP Array 6.0 was used for genotyping and confirmed homozygous regions at chromosome 2q11 between RS2628473 and RS1901284 which contained 11 candidate genes via Sanger sequencing.
evidence.rdfs:label: Gaza B_V:4

evidence.dc:description: Downgrading the score because the individuals is homozygous, per discussion with the Experts in the Retina GCEP.

Immunofluorescence of mouse retina sections labeled with rabbit anti-cnnm4 antibody shows expression in photoreceptor inner segments, and predominantly localized to the outer plexiform layer (OPL), inner plexiform layer (IPL), and ganglion cell layer (GCL), containing the axons, dendrites, and synaptic terminals of the neuronal cells of the retina.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse retinal expression

evidence.dc:description: Paraffin-embedded sections of  demineralized rat incisor was labeled with anti-CNNM4 antibody detected expression in ameloblasts during transition and maturation which is consistent with the tissue affected in Jalili syndrome.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression of CNNM4 in rat incisor

evidence.dc:description: Immunostaining of 2-day old mouse incisor shows expression in all tissues of the mandible specifically in ameloblasts and odontoblasts.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in mouse incisor

evidence.dc:description: Mg2+ extrusion assays were performed measuring the fluorescence intensity of transfected constructs over time (0-5min).  Wild type relative intensity decreased rapidly after Mg2+ depletion began, while missense mutations display very weak, if any, Mg2+ extrusion activity similar to empty vector relative intensities.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Transcellular Mg(2+) transport across epithelia, involving both apical entry and basolateral extrusion, is essential for magnesium homeostasis, but molecules involved in basolateral extrusion have not yet been identified. Here, we show that CNNM4 is the basolaterally located Mg(2+) extrusion molecule. CNNM4 is strongly expressed in intestinal epithelia and localizes to their basolateral membrane. CNNM4-knockout mice showed hypomagnesemia due to the intestinal malabsorption of magnesium, suggesting its role in Mg(2+) extrusion to the inner parts of body. Imaging analyses revealed that CNNM4 can extrude Mg(2+) by exchanging intracellular Mg(2+) with extracellular Na(+). Furthermore, CNNM4 mutations cause Jalili syndrome, characterized by recessive amelogenesis imperfecta with cone-rod dystrophy. CNNM4-knockout mice showed defective amelogenesis, and CNNM4 again localizes to the basolateral membrane of ameloblasts, the enamel-forming epithelial cells. Missense point mutations associated with the disease abolish the Mg(2+) extrusion activity. These results demonstrate the crucial importance of Mg(2+) extrusion by CNNM4 in organismal and topical regulation of magnesium.
dc:source.dc:creator: Yamazaki D
dc:source.dc:title: Basolateral Mg2+ extrusion via CNNM4 mediates transcellular Mg2+ transport across epithelia: a mouse model.

evidence.rdfs:label: HEK293 studies

evidence.dc:description: Control, knock down and rescue morphants were assessed at 5 days post fertilization (dpf) for defects in morphology in toluidine blue-stained sections.  Knock down had a 35% reduction in ganglion cells, rescue with human CNNM4 mRNA was able to rescue reduction by 50%.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue of cnnm4 morpholino knock down in zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Malabsorption of Mg2+ in mice knockouts result in defects in amelogenesis.  Hypomineralization is seen in tooth enamel in knock out mice similar to defects in enamel formation in hypomaturation Amelogenesis imperfecta in patients with mutations in CNNM4.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cnnm4-/- mouse model

evidence.dc:description: The phenotype of the mouse model recapitulated the AI, however no signs of CRD was seen in KO mice.

dc:description: CNNM4 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Jalili syndrome which causes cone rod dystrophy and amelogenesis imperfecta (AI) in 2009 (Parry et al., 19200525). At least four missense variants, three nonsense variants, and one frameshift variant have been reported in humans. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 10 probands in 2 publications (19200525, 19200527). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 33 additional family members.  Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence and/or experimental evidence (12 pts.) has been reached.  This gene-disease association is supported by several lines of experimental evidence including the expression of CNNM4 in retina and incisors in mice (19200525, 19200527), enamel defects similar to AI in a mouse model (24339795), along with rescue studies in zebrafish (19200527).  In summary, CNNM4 is definitively associated with autosomal recessive Jalili syndrome.  This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.
